snippet.textDisplay:
as much as i'd love a Tesla or an electric car in general, i think pushing for that tech right now is very fatal and totally the wrong move. It just isn't there yet. Range aside, which isn't even as much of a problem as some people make it out to be, these batteries are extremely expensive, can be very dangerous if damaged (electric cars can burn for days after an accident), the infrastructure still isn't really there yet (pretty sure the oil industry makes sure it stays that way as long as possible) but most importantly, the energy infrastructure simply isn't there yet. These car's are not only extremely dirty to produce, but they also effectively run on coal power for the most part, let's be honest.


There are quiet a few alternatives that would be a much better option at the moment and that would be a reasonable and better intermediate step, like hydrogen cars for examples. It isn't that electric cars aren't there yet, but rather that everything surrounding it still isn't. Ultimately electric cars are clearly the future, which is kinda ironic considering electric cars are as old if not older than ones with combustion engines after all.

snippet.textDisplay:
Great test, thanks!
Still, I will keep my Skoda Octavia diesel 2013 for a while yet. I get an actual range of some 1150-1200 km (ca720 miles) before the lamp lights up telling me to fill up (there might still be another 150-200 km in there, but you don't run it dry), it matches the claimed consumption to 100% and it cost me £10.000 three years ago!

I would consider a hybrid for my next car though - then you get the electric for daily communte to work but still the long range.
snippet.textOriginal:
Great test, thanks!
Still, I will keep my Skoda Octavia diesel 2013 for a while yet. I get an actual range of some 1150-1200 km (ca720 miles) before the lamp lights up telling me to fill up (there might still be another 150-200 km in there, but you don't run it dry), it matches the claimed consumption to 100% and it cost me £10.000 three years ago!

I would consider a hybrid for my next car though - then you get the electric for daily communte to work but still the long range.

snippet.textDisplay:
Say the Kia e-Niro cost £38,000. No road tax and 90% less fuel cost over 10 years. Saving £2000 fuel cost per year = £20,000 over the 10 years.
Meaning the actual cost of the car is £18,000.
Is that the tipping point for electric cars to be cheaper than petrol and diesel ?

Say the Kia e-Niro cost £38,000. No road tax and 90% less fuel cost over 10 years. Saving £2000 fuel cost per year = £20,000 over the 10 years.

snippet.textDisplay:
When I see people at charging stations, plugged up to charger and the charger is plugged up to a diesel generator, I fucking laugh my ass off.
I live in San Francisco and I've had conversations with people who own Tesla's, who have NEVER considered the where the electricity comes from in the first place, I've heard people arguing with other people, saying that process is 100% green, that fossil fuels are never in the picture 😭
I love taking pictures of people plugged up to the charging stations, when the diesel generator is running, LOLOL

snippet.textDisplay:
How long to recharge each? A fuel powered vehicle takes maybe 5 minutes and you are on your way again. Plus what vehicles fuel only go 200 miles before refueling. The wife Volvo S60 goes 400-440 miles even my F150 truck does 300-380 miles (all depending on speed). So while you are stopped charging I am continuing on and still taking 5-10 minutes to fuel up. I'm not impressed, battery technology needs to get better, holding more power, lighter cells and 5-10 minute recharging times. Then again in the United States it's not uncommon for me to drive 1200 miles in one long day. Typically I will do 800 miles and grab a Hotel but not always sometimes I just want to get back to my bed. I do this drive 1-2 times a year.

Maybe with the electric trucks coming out they can have bigger batteries thus go further too and that will make them more usable. Then the cost comes into play, I really don't want to spend $60,000-$70,000 on a fuel vehicle and being electric they probably put it at $80,000-$90,000...um NO I bought my F150 on A/Z-Plan for $30,000 off the commercial lot brand new. I'm not paying $$$$ for a truck or any vehicle, granted the wife's was nutty at $45,000 but we own it and that brings me to the other thing.

How long will an electric vehicle last? I plan each vehicle we own to last 15-20 years. The wife's is a 2013 and mine is a 2016 (however bought new in 2017 so miles didn't start till then). So for hers we plan 2028 as a minimum and me 2032. Then again I only plan to own 1 maybe 2 new cars myself...the wife probably one. Vehicles are a huge waste of money/wealth.

snippet.textDisplay:
Definitely feels like Mercedes and Audi are dropping the ball, while Kia's the big winner.


The luxo brands look like they just slapped a battery and motor in there without trying to figure out how they work. Terrible efficiency.


Tesla is obviously the benchmark. They are brand new to the car industry. They didn't just have to invest in battery/motor technology, they had to develop suspension and safety and manufacturing from nothing. The major brands had all the other things for years, and only needed to dump some of their budget into electric development. And they still can't beat Tesla. That's terrible.


Kia, at least, seems to be giving a decent try at it. Props to them.
snippet.textOriginal:
Definitely feels like Mercedes and Audi are dropping the ball, while Kia's the big winner.


The luxo brands look like they just slapped a battery and motor in there without trying to figure out how they work.  Terrible efficiency.


Tesla is obviously the benchmark.  They are brand new to the car industry.  They didn't just have to invest in battery/motor technology, they had to develop suspension and safety and manufacturing from nothing.  The major brands had all the other things for years, and only needed to dump some of their budget into electric development.  And they still can't beat Tesla.  That's terrible.


Kia, at least, seems to be giving a decent try at it.  Props to them.

snippet.textDisplay: What were the sizes of the batteries in each of these vehicles?  What was the average mileage per kw/h?  If the Tesla was a 75kWh battery, it averaged 3.6 miles/kwh.  The Niro averaged ~4 miles/kWh with it's 64kWh battery.  If the Leaf was the 62 kWh variant it averaged ~ 3.35 miles/kWh.  A summary of these things at the end could be very helpful to the consumer.
snippet.textOriginal: What were the sizes of the batteries in each of these vehicles?  What was the average mileage per kw/h?  If the Tesla was a 75kWh battery, it averaged 3.6 miles/kwh.  The Niro averaged ~4 miles/kWh with it's 64kWh battery.  If the Leaf was the 62 kWh variant it averaged ~ 3.35 miles/kWh.  A summary of these things at the end could be very helpful to the consumer.
